review_title: Decent place to work as a rehab CNA
job_title: Certified Nurse Aide in New York, NY
pros: this is probably the best rehab a CNA can work at. Patient load is lower than other places (usually only 7 patients per shift) and lots of patients are independent since this is only a short-term rehab, the nurses are nice and admin is very nice as well.
cons: very short staffed at times, especially the night and during the winter. Some days there'll only be one CNA (which means you'll have 21 patients) and one nurse for two different floors.

job_title: Associate Director in Long Island-Queens
pros: Benefits comparable to other jobs Co-workers are friendly
cons: Lay-offs are constant and make us nervous Poor morale Few career pathway or promotions Hybrid work promised but not followed through

job_title: Finance in New York, NY
pros: Work from home is an option but you're encouraged to go in
cons: Toxic attitudes ("I'm the boss") and extremely short staffed and told to hire any warm body to fill positions. So many under-qualified people there trying to do work well outside of their experience.

job_title: Management in New York, NY
pros: The toxic working environment encourages bonding among employees, and as a result strong friendships are formed.
cons: I was in a mid-management level position. The senior management team is only interested in filling their own pockets.  The wellbeing of patients and quality of care are no longer a priority. Not only does senior management overlook hostile treatment of employees, they encourage it. I expressed my concern about the hostile behavior that I witnessed and was told by an executive, that it ok for a high level manager to bully employees, because that person is good at his/her job. The executives do not want to hear your thoughts. There is only one way to do things…their way. If you want to be part of a company where you can collaborate and share ideas, this is not the place. I left the company because I could not accept that the way to manage, is to call employees idiots and humiliate them in front of their peers. I am now in a new position and can again sleep at night.

job_title: Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Laid-back work enviroment compare to other company
cons:
This is a company they do not focus on what is your work performance and how much case you finish every months. What they care about is did you have a good relationship with your supervisor or director. Some lazy and unproductive  staff stay in this company more than 6 years. What they do everyday in office is play the phone, listen to the music and gossipi personal topic. Too much office political in this company. That is why this company have a very low enrollment rate than other company. Also, you do not get enough training before you really start your job. The skill you need to work in here is buy coffee to your supervisor, listen your coworker personal gossip. Like kids, boyfriend and office love affair. Those staff they usually push their work to new employees. And they left office like 4:30 or 5: 00.
Don't waste your time in here if you get other job offer. You can not learning anything in here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Benefits 
1. Health Insurance 
2. Life Insurance 

Lessons Learned
1. Sanity over Salary
2. Never allow anyone to alter your morals, values, or virtues to keep employment
cons:
Too much management staff with little qualifications, education, and experience. 

Very minimal training

No quality in the care for patients

Too many "quotas"

The management department needs serious training on how to deal and work with staff

Over worked, highly underpaid (Caseloads over 130; $35,000 salary or lower)

Promotions with no salary increase

job_title: Clinical Operations Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Working in the field, diversity
cons: Disorganized, unprofessional, favoritism, micromanage, money hungry

job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: Supervisors and directors were a pleasure to work with.
cons: Before I resigned (due to relocation outside of NYC), our company phones were installed with GPS locator. Staff and administrators can keep track of your whereabouts while out on the field.  This made many workers feel as though they were being micromanaged.

job_title: Care Coordinator (Utilization Management) in New York, NY
pros:
Ability to work from home
Caring and Pleasant Team Leads and Managers
Opportunities to excel and grow as long as you work Hard
Managers constantly express appreciation both individually and to their team as a whole.
cons: Can effect work life balance if you let it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Not an employer who functions from a philosophy of best management practice.
cons: Shows next to no desire to serve the poor and sick whose services are their responsibility because of Medicaid funding.  Sales and marketing are the focus of Villagecare.  People in charge have no higher education in clinical fields or management. Employees treated very poorly and severely overworked so that more can be billed to Medicaid yet clients receive little to no aervice.  Huge caseloads prevent genuine service. Salaries for new hires are low.

job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: Salary and team RN do the best they can but it is not feasible
cons: Case Management is losing CM left and right because the there is too much work to be done.  150 caseload expectations, daily calls, take member requests that have many process. Biweekly productivity reports for all to see,  weekly threats by management for not meeting quota. Do not care about the care Managers only upper management.  Sad but I feel sorry for anyone who has to work here as a case manager.  Don’t do it.

job_title: RN Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: Decent benefits and pay/compensation, allows you to WAH, mostly independent, you are given your own cellphone
cons: Expected to work long hours/overtime w/o pay; unfair and unrealistic expectations; caseload can be overwhelming; software system (eCare) is horrible; called into the office too many times when trainings, mtgs, etc. could have been done online or over the phone; favoritism and partiality towards certain employees

job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: Relatively stable, good solidarity with coworkers
cons: Upper management is size and money focused, not healthcare focused. Insurance benefits are awful, communication is lacking, job roles are unclear, lots of leadership with little applicable experience and not much training to fix that, which becomes clear when issues arise and staff tries to express needs for solutions.

job_title: Healthcare Professional in New York, NY
pros: This used to be a great place to work. The focus was on patient care. This mission of promoting health and wellbeing no longer applies for patients, members or staff.
cons: Retaliatory, intimidating environment. If you express your feeling or concerns your are reprimanded and targeted. You are told what do, opinions and ideas are not welcome.

job_title: Health Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: overall good direct supervisors, very good team work and colleagues,  value excellent customer service to client.
cons: strong favoritism, very poor work/life balance, overwhelming expected OT (I am in school and making it worse), new hire gets 3 weeks of vacation instead of 4, poor medical benefit coverage and changes every year and getting worse each year, not enough staff appreciation from company, often have urgent issues or projects that need staff to resolve that distract employees from focusing on their primary daily function.

job_title: Team Leader in New York, NY
pros: Decent salary and benefits.
cons: Definitely quantity over quality, Numbers Numbers Numbers. Little to no support from management particularly when issues arise. Case loads skyrocketing and continually increase each month. Lots of time spent on public transportation to visit each client.
